Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Selenium redox reactions and isotope ratios: The role of microbial and abiotic Selenium oxidation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Selenium (Se) is an essential micronutrient, a potential environmental contaminant, and an indicator of chemical reactions involving oxidation and reduction, in both present and past environmental systems. Chemical and biological processes control the mobility and environmental impact of Se. Although Se oxidation is an important Se-mobilizing process, our understanding of this process is limited. Additionally, although measurements of variations in Se stable isotope abundances (82Se/76Se ratios) provide a powerful new way to study key chemical reactions involving Se in modern and ancient environments, poor understanding of Se stable isotope shifts caused by Se oxidation limits interpretation of Se isotope data. Therefore, this project will investigate stable Se isotope variation caused by oxidation as a means to achieve a robust understanding of Se oxidation in the environment. Investigators will train one postdoctoral fellow, two doctoral students, and 6-8 undergraduate students per year through programs that target underrepresented students. The societal benefits of this project include communications with the concerned governmental agencies to enable better assessments of Se fate linked to human nutritional adequacy, toxic thresholds and the fundamental understanding of Se in the earth system.

The scope of the project is to integrate stable isotope geochemistry and microbiology to gain an improved understanding of biotic and abiotic Se oxidation. The specific objectives are to (1) demonstrate that microbial Se oxidation supports chemoautotrophic growth, (2) determine the magnitude of Se isotopic fractionation caused by microbial and abiotic oxidation of reduced Se-species, and (3) examine oxidation of Se in natural soil/sediment matrices to determine how the laboratory-derived fractionation factors will apply in natural environments. Controlled laboratory experiments will be conducted to determine reaction rates and Se isotope fractionation during microbial and abiotic Se oxidation. Slurry experiments with soils and sediments of two different field sites will provide complementary understanding of Se oxidation in natural samples under well-defined conditions. By establishing a link between Se oxidation and Se isotope fractionation, the results will open new avenues for studies of Se cycling and the fate of Se as a micronutrient and contaminant.

Intellectual Merit:

Selenium is an essential micronutrient for microorganisms and animals, but it has also recently emerged as an environmental contaminant, released from geological sources by human activity, including irrigation. Chemical and biological processes control the mobility of selenium, and consequently its toxicity and environmental impact. In the global selenium cycle, selenium oxidation is thought to play a central role in the dissolution of selenium-bearing minerals and of elemental selenium, and in the production of soluble selenium (selenite and selenate) that is transferred from continental to marine reservoirs. Although oxidation is an important process controlling selenium fluxes in natural environments, very little is known about the mechanisms involved and the reaction rates. Therefore, it is crucial to understand which processes control selenium oxidation to predict the mobilization of selenium in soils and ultimately the uptake of selenium by plants and animals. We consequently focused our work on understanding both bacterial and abiotic selenium oxidation.

Through this project, we isolated several bacterial species that were able to oxidize elemental selenium from selenium-rich soils. One of the bacteria, designated as Bacillus megaterium strain JG-17, showed a stronger selenium oxidation activity than other isolates, and the inability to reduce selenium, and was consequently selected as a model organism to investigate the mechanisms for bacterial selenium oxidation. We showed that strain JG-17 indirectly solubilizes elemental selenium via the release of extracellular sulfur compounds. Such findings suggest that the production of reactive sulfur species by soil microorganisms can promote selenium mobilization during chemical weathering, which could also have implications for other sulfur-reactive chemical elements.

Our work also brought new knowledge about selenium (selenite and elemental selenium) abiotic oxidation and dissolution by a range of common soil minerals, including manganese oxides, as well as iron and sulfur compounds. Specifically, it provided useful insights on the influence of pH, as well as particle size and concentration of birnessite, an environmentally-relevant manganese oxide, on selenium sorption and oxidation, which affect selenium mobility in natural systems.

We showed that oxidation of selenium in natural soils is a rapid process, leading to selenium release to water. Such results have implications not only for understanding selenium cycling in situ, but also for optimizing soil washing solutions used to remediate selenium-contaminated soils. The fast and elevated release of selenium we observed for experiments with groundwater confirms that extensive irrigation with groundwater as performed in situ could lead to selenium mobilization and contamination of groundwater. Our results also indicated that addition of sulfate at environmentally-relevant concentrations and of hydrogen peroxide to washing solutions would be an efficient way to increase selenium extraction efficiency in the process of soil remediation.

We observed a small selenium isotopic fractionation for selenium oxidation in natural soils and by manganese oxides and for selenite sorption to manganese oxides, much smaller than the range most commonly seen for selenium reduction. This implies that selenium isotope data in environmental settings can be interpreted largely in terms of reduction effects.

Overall, our results led to an improved understanding of how bacterial and abiotic selenium oxidation affects selenium mobilization during chemical weathering, which has important implications for the development of reliable models that describe modern and ancient selenium biogeochemical cycles. Additionally, by combining selenium isotope fractionation induced by oxidation pathways with current knowledge of selenium isotope shifts induced by reduction, we will be able to interpret data from systems with fluctuating redox conditions (e.g., weathering environments and shallow aquifers) or spatial redox contrasts (e.g., oxidative terrestrial weathering combined with reductive marine deposition).

Broader Impacts:

Our project has provided research opportunities at UC Berkeley for two postdoctoral fellows, three graduate students, and three undergraduate students. Half of those participants were female students, and all undegrdauate students identified themselves as underrepresented minorities. The results of our work have provided new information about the mechanisms of microbial selenium oxidation and abiotic selenium mobilizing processes in soil environments, improving our knowledge of selenium biogeochemical cycling. The findings will enhance the understanding of selenium mobilizing processes in order to improve contaminant remediation strategies and agricultural practices.
